column1: Willingboro Township is a township in Burlington County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States
column4: with British roots going back to the 17th century. Abraham Levitt and Sons purchased and developed Willingboro land in the 1950s and 1960s as a planned community in their Levittown model.The 1967 book The Levittowners
column6: was a famous case study in American urban sociology based on the development of Levittown. Willingboro later became a predominantly African American suburb.

column1: Willingboro was one of the original nine divisions in the organization of Burlington County within West Jersey
column2: and was originally formed as the "Constabulary of Wellingborrow" on November 6
column3: 1688. At the time
column4: it included present day Delanco Township
column5: New Jersey. The original name of Wellingborough was after the community in England
column6: which was the hometown of Thomas Ollive
column7: who led the original settlers into what would become Willingboro Township. Other spellings were used at different times.

column1: After the establishment of the United States and the State of New Jersey
column2: the community was formally incorporated as "Willingborough Township"
column3: one of New Jersey's initial group of 104 townships
column6: by the New Jersey Legislature when it enacted "An Act incorporating the Inhabitants of Townships
column10: p. 289. This makes Willingboro one of the oldest townships in the State.

column1: Portions of the township were taken to form Beverly borough (March 5
column3: now Beverly city) and Beverly Township (March 1
column5: now known as Delanco Township).In the 1950s and 1960s
column6: Willingboro was the location for a massive residential development by Levitt & Sons. The town was to be Levitt & Sons' third and largest Levittown development
column7: following similar projects in New York and Pennsylvania. Levitt acquired the great majority of the land in Willingboro; the historic community of Rancocas
column8: in the southeast portion of the township
column9: was annexed to Westampton Township to keep it from being bulldozed
column10: as Levitt wished to keep the development within the boundaries of a single municipality. The first Levittown homes were sold in June 1958
column11: at which time the community was already known as Levittown
column13: the 1950 population of 852 rapidly climbed to 11
column15: 386 in 1970. The community used the name "Levittown
column17: and "Levittown Township" from 1959 to 1963.The town's name was changed from the original Willingboro to "Levittown Township" by a referendum of township residents held on November 3
column18: 1959. Willingboro was less than 12 miles (19 km) from Levittown
column19: Pennsylvania and this occasionally caused confusion.  A referendum held on the issue on November 5
column21: changed the name back to Willingboro. The name change was passed by a narrow margin of 3
column24: Levitt refused to donate any more schools to the fast-growing community.When homes for the new Levittown were first being sold in 1958
column25: Levitt and Sons had a policy against sales to African Americans. W. R. James
column26: an African-American officer in the Army's Criminal Investigation Division
column27: was stationed at nearby Fort Dix and applied to purchase a Levittown home. On June 29
column29: an agent of Levitt and Sons told him that the new Levittown development would be an all-white community. James filed suit against the company challenging their policy. A friend of his
column30: who worked at the New Jersey Division of Civil Rights
column31: said that it was illegal in New Jersey to discriminate in federally-subsidized housing. At the time
column32: de facto racial segregation in housing existed in many areas in the United States. Levittown was receiving mortgage insurance from the Federal Housing Administration. But as of 1958
column33: the law had not been tested.James sued Levitt in a case that ultimately went to the New Jersey Supreme Court
column34: which upheld lower court rulings in favor of James. James was not the first African American to move into Willingboro. Given James' success in his suit
column35: Charles and Vera Williams purchased a house and moved into the community in 1960
column36: the first African-American family in Willingboro. James eventually moved into Millbrook Park in 1960.  He served as head of the local chapter of the NAACP and eventually became a minister. An elementary school in Willingboro was named in his honor.Following the court case
column37: Levitt developed a thorough integration program. The company set up an integration committee headed by Howard Lett
column38: an African American. Lett created a five-point program
column39: which included the announcement by community leaders of Levitt's plan to desegregate housing
column40: and a thorough briefing program for Levitt employees
column42: the police and the press. Lett recommended an attempt to discourage anti-integration activities known as "Operation Hothead". Lett created a Human Relations Council to oversee possible disputes in community. James served as a member of that committee. The committee tried to solve problems of juvenile delinquency in the township. It opposed a curfew passed by the Township Council in the early 1970s. The curfew was later dropped
column43: but reintroduced later. One area that the committee oversaw was the practice of blockbusting.

column1: The African-American population of Willingboro increased throughout the 1960s; by 1964 there were 50 African-American families. By 1970
column2: African Americans represented about 11% of the population. During the early 1970s
column3: several homeowners said they were approached by local real estate agents and told that their neighborhood was becoming increasingly African-American and home values could decline if they did not sell quickly; a practice known as blockbusting. While the Human Relations Council could not prove these claims
column4: it made recommendations to help foster better relations between ethnic communities in the township and calm concerns.The township in 1974 enacted an ordinance that prohibited the posting of "for sale" or "sold" signs on real estate. Proponents of the ordinance alleged the purpose was to maintain integration.  Many other communities had enacted similar laws in reaction to the practice of blockbusting in the 1960s and 1970s. The Supreme Court in the 1977 case of Linmark Associates
column5: Inc. v. Willingboro ruled that the ordinance violated the First Amendment protections for free speech
column6: which applied to commercial needs.As of the 2010 United States Census
column11: which had in turn declined by 3

column3: including 7.73 square miles (20.01 km2) of land and 0.41 square miles (1.07 km2) of water (5.09%).The township borders the Burlington County municipalities of Burlington Township
column8: Mount Laurel Township and Westampton Township. Rancocas Creek drains Willingboro and forms its SW boundary while U.S. Route 130 forms its NW boundary.

column1: Willingboro is divided into several sections
column2: each section's street names beginning with the same letter as the corresponding section name.  For example
column3: streets in Pennypacker Park all begin with the letter "P". This is the case with all parks
column4: excluding Martin's Beach and certain streets in Rittenhouse Park.  Some streets that predate Levittown retained their original names

column2: each Park or section had its own swimming pool for residents' use.  Residents' families would receive free swim tags after showing applicable IDs at each section's school or the community office. However
column3: some swimming pools
column5: have been inactive for years. Free lessons and other events were focused on these "park" pools during the summer months.  By the 1990s
column6: only Pennypacker Park and Country Club Park had operating summer pools.  Finally
column7: Country Club Park has been denoted the "community pool" at this time.

column1: Fairmount ParkA section without a name is located near Olympia Lakes.  This is the only part of the town with the area code 856.  The rest of Willingboro is in area code 609.

Willingboro has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa) and average monthly temperatures in the vicinity of Levitt Parkway and Willingboro Parkway range from 32.8° F in January to 76.5° F in July. The local hardiness zone is 7a.

column1: The Township of Willingboro is governed within the Faulkner Act
column2: formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law
column3: under the Council-Manager form of government (Plan E)
column4: enacted by direct petition and implemented as of January 1
column5: 1962. The township is one of 42 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The current Council-Manager form of government was adopted by referendum in November 1960 based on the recommendations of a Charter Study Commission. The elections for the first council to operate under the new Council-Manager form of government took place in November 1961
column6: with the new council taking office as of January 1
column8: under the new form. The Township Council is comprised of five members
column9: who are elected in partisan elections to serve four-year terms in office on a staggered basis
column10: with two or three seats coming up for election as part of the November general election during odd-numbered years. At a reorganization held during the first week of January after each election
column11: the council selects a Mayor and Deputy Mayor from among its members.As of 2020
column12: the members of the Willingboro Township Council are Mayor Dr. Tiffani A. Worthy (D
column16: term on council ends 2023; term as deputy mayor ends 2020)
column21: the council selected Rebecca Perone from a list of three candidates nominated by the Democratic municipal committee to fill the seat that had been held by Christopher "Chris" Walker expiring in December 2019 until he resigned from his post as mayor in June 2017.The Township Council appointed Chris Walker in October 2013 to fill the vacant seat of Ken Gordon
column22: after a New Jersey Superior Court judge ruled that Gordon's seat was vacant based on his having missed a series of council meetings. Eddie Campbell was named to fill Gordon's former position as deputy mayor. Darvis Holley was appointed in April 2014 to fill the vacant seat of Jim Ayrer
column23: who had resigned after serving on the council for 34 years.

column1: The Willingboro Township Public Schools serves students in pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade. As of the 2017–18 school year
column2: the district
column3: comprised of eight schools
column5: 203 students and 272.0 classroom teachers (on an FTE basis)
column6: for a student–teacher ratio of 11.8:1. Schools in the district (with 2017–18 enrollment data from the National Center for Education Statistics) are

column1: J. Cresswell Stuart Early Childhood Development Center for PreK-K
Garfield East Early Childhood Development Center for PreK-K
Hawthorne Elementary School with 393 students in grades 1–4
W.R. James Sr. Elementary School with 349 students in grades 1–4
Twin Hills Elementary School with 312 students in grades 1–4
Levitt Intermediate School with NA students in grades 5–6
Willingboro Memorial Middle School with 677 students in grades 7–8
Willingboro High School with 632 students in grades 9-12 and
Alternative School at Bookbinder served 18 students in grades 6-12.During the early development of the township
column2: all high school students attended Levittown High School for grades 9-12 (LHS was renamed "Levitt Jr. High School" when the new high school - John F. Kennedy - was opened in 1964). It was the only junior high school
column3: grades 7 through 9
column4: until Memorial Junior High School opened in 1968. The substantial student population at JFK HS required that the school go to split sessions and only was able to house grades 10–12
column5: with the freshmen classes divided between Memorial and Levitt junior high schools. In 1975
column6: Willingboro HS was opened and became the "sister" school
column7: located only about two miles apart - both on JFK Way. This is the way the township was until JFK HS became a middle school in 1990
column8: leaving Willingboro as the only high school. By this time
column9: the township population fell and Levitt Junior High School was closed to become township offices and storage. Memorial Junior High School would remain open for college classes for Burlington County College. Kennedy Middle School eventually closed and became Kennedy Center
column10: a community center for the performing arts

column2: J.A. McGinley and Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary Schools were closed at the end of the 2005–06 school year as part of an effort to save about $3.6 million
column3: through the reduction of as many as 100 staff members and class sizes increased as large as 27 at the five remaining elementary schools. The cuts were needed to fill a two-year budget deficit of nearly $10 million.Students from Willingboro Township
column4: and from all of Burlington County
column5: are eligible to attend the Burlington County Institute of Technology
column6: a countywide public school district that serves the vocational and technical education needs of students at the high school and post-secondary level at its campuses in Medford and Westampton Township.The Willingboro Public Library (WPL) is the municipal public library for the community. It first opened in 1960 and operates independently from the Burlington County Library System. Before 2003
column7: the library was housed in the township's municipal building on Salem Road. The current library building is 42
column9: 900 m2). and is an anchor for the new Willingboro Town Center on Route 130.

column2: the township had a total of 122.11 miles (196.52 km) of roadways
column3: of which 109.02 miles (175.45 km) were maintained by the municipality
column4: 11.53 miles (18.56 km) by Burlington County and 1.56 miles (2.51 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation.U.S. Route 130 is the main highway serving Willingboro. It straddles the township's borders with Delanco Township and Edgewater Park Township.

column1: NJ Transit provides bus service on 409 / 417 / 418 routes between Trenton and Philadelphia.BurLink bus service is offered on the B1 route (between Beverly and Pemberton) and on the B2 route (between Beverly and Westampton Township).Academy Bus provides service from Willingboro and at the park-and-ride facility near Exit 5 of the New Jersey Turnpike in Westampton to the Port Authority Bus Terminal and other street service in Midtown Manhattan and to both Jersey City and the Wall Street area in Lower Manhattan.
